instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02

Fan Spin = OK

ALL MAIN RAILS ARE PRESENT AND AS IT SHOULD
I ALREADY REPLACE BIOS IN ORDER TO GET IT WORKING NO SUCCESS
CPU GETS HOTS

Tried to check external image.. also NO IMAGE

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
Did you check USB activity too?

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?
Any history available?

Did you check USB activity too?

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?

Actually when I plugged external hard drive the light turns on... but it seems energy light not working light, when I plugged on a working machine it turtns on and then starts blinking as it reads the HD

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.32V

Customer left a bottle of water opened with the computer... so it was water damage and when I opened I saw it around DC-IN board to be honest... But already tried another DC-IN board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
Damaged caused by corrosion.
Inspect all SPI Bus Termination resistors and their traces.
Clean/remove J6100.

Did you get the BIOS file from the forum?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message: Actually I replace the BIOS with another one from the same board number of a working board. So BIOS is not the issue right? I will check everything related to the SPI Bus Termination as you said

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
That BIOS has dirty ME region, but is not a reason to avoid the boot.
Inspect for corrosion under microscope.

You can try to heat PCH area with quality flux; may have accumulated crap underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
Sorry my mistake this board did not have any water damaged I make confusion the behavior is as descripted above except water damage.

Measure all the resistors on the SPI BUS SERIES TERMINATION and all of them and giving the number according to the schematic

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message: Would it be related to RAM?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
Check all LPC bus resistors.

Could be bad CPU, or just a simple resistor damaged in the PCH/CPU area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message: Can you give me more info about heating the PCH?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message: All LPC resistors are matching schematics

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message: Actually <RESISTOR>R1614</RESISTOR> is giving me 75kohms and its supposed to be 100kohms.. Is it bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message: Which resistors should I measure on the CPU/PCH line.. Can you give me better hints I will try my best to find and measure all of them

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
Could be one from 100 resistors.
No clue apart of classic tests.
Just in case, check all PECI related components.
Also check all L/C blocks  next the CPU; near the board edge (1V05 rails).

We have several posts describing how to heat BGA chips, in case of accumulated underneath crap.
Remember, you don't need to melt the balls.
180-200 degrees for 15-20 sec should be good enough; chip temp, not hot air station settings!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
PECI 2 resistors are FINE
Not sure what are all L/C blocks

I only do have hot air station (Quick 861DW), Is it possible to heat the CPU with it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message: I reballed the SMC... It had some gray pads under it... Now I would say its fine. What else could be? CPU gets HOT

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
"what are all L/C blocks"
L=coil, C=capacitor; L1290, <CAPACITOR>C1290</CAPACITOR>, etc...

threads.message:
Got it!

Visually inspecting everything seems normal. Are you advising me to measure voltage on those area? All coils and those BIG caps?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
Didnt tried that since I am not 100% sure which area is the PCH one. The older models like <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> have a big PCH... this one is integrated with the CPU right? So I should HEAT the CPU? Or am I wrong?

Since I ONLY have a QUICK 861DW HOT AIR STATION..

How to properly approach it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
threads.message:
Didn't see two Si dies on the CPU?
Guess which is which?
If you follow PCH lines in schematic, where they go?
Boardview should help better.

We discussed so many times about heating BGAs on the forum.
I gave you some temp/time values; you should use 20-30% of air flow.
As I said, the temp refers to chip, not to hot air station.
To achive 200 degrees on the board, the station must be set at 350-400 degress; depends the model and every unit has also its tollerance.
Distance hot air nozzle to board also must be considered.
You should practice with scrap boards.
Is all about practice, we all do it at "the eyes" (only one in my case).

The goal is to burn eventually accumulated crap underneath, not to melt the balls.
Once the (good quality) flux starts to boil, shouldn't increase the temp too much; don't exceed the time.

BTW, the role of the forum is to assist on the repair process.
For personal training, contact Rossmann staff...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
